identificationModule.briefTitle: Subscapularis Repair in Reverse Shoulder Arthroplasty
identificationModule.officialTitle: Subscapularis Repair in Reverse Shoulder Arthroplasty: a Randomized, Controlled, Multicenter, Prospective Study

descriptionModule.briefSummary: This study will evaluate the subscapularis repair versus non-repair during a reverse shoulder arthroplasty (RSA).
descriptionModule.detailedDescription:
The primary objective of this study is to evaluate pain and function in patients undergoing RSA with or without subscapularis repair. This primary outcome will be measured by analysis of Constant scores at two years post-operative.

Secondary objectives are to evaluate pain, function and imaging, between the two groups at each applicable time point.

designInfo.interventionModelDescription: The patients will be randomly allocated in a 1:1 ratio, with block sizes of four and six using a randomization sequence.

armGroups.label: Reverse Shoulder Arthroplasty with subscapularis repair
armGroups.description: The subscapularis will be repaired using the "suture through bone and prosthesis holes" surgical technique.

armGroups.label: Reverse Shoulder Arthroplasty without subscapularis repair
armGroups.description: The subscapularis will not be repaired.

interventions.name: Repair of the subscapularis
interventions.description: The subscapularis will be repaired using the "suture through bone and prosthesis holes" surgical technique.
armGroupLabels: Reverse Shoulder Arthroplasty with subscapularis repair

primaryOutcomes.description: A combination of objective measures and patient-reported outcomes. It defines the level of pain and the ability to carry out the normal daily activities of the patient. It is a 0-100 point scale, the higher the score, the higher the quality of the function.
primaryOutcomes.timeFrame: Collected at at pre-op, but the primary outcome is the score at 2 years post-procedure.

primaryOutcomes.description: A combination of objective measures and patient-reported outcomes. It defines the level of pain and the ability to carry out the normal daily activities of the patient. It is a 0-100 point scale, the higher the score, the higher the quality of the function.
primaryOutcomes.timeFrame: Collected at at 9 week post-op timepoint, but the primary outcome is the score at 2 years post-procedure.

primaryOutcomes.description: A combination of objective measures and patient-reported outcomes. It defines the level of pain and the ability to carry out the normal daily activities of the patient. It is a 0-100 point scale, the higher the score, the higher the quality of the function.
primaryOutcomes.timeFrame: Collected at at the 26 week post-op timepoint, but the primary outcome is the score at 2 years post-procedure.

primaryOutcomes.description: A combination of objective measures and patient-reported outcomes. It defines the level of pain and the ability to carry out the normal daily activities of the patient. It is a 0-100 point scale, the higher the score, the higher the quality of the function.
primaryOutcomes.timeFrame: Collected at at 1 year post-op timepoint, but the primary outcome is the score at 2 years post-procedure.

primaryOutcomes.description: A combination of objective measures and patient-reported outcomes. It defines the level of pain and the ability to carry out the normal daily activities of the patient. It is a 0-100 point scale, the higher the score, the higher the quality of the function.
primaryOutcomes.timeFrame: Collected at the 2 year post-op timepoint, and is the primary outcome measure

secondaryOutcomes.description: Evaluation of the subscapularis complex in patients that have been randomized to "repair of the subscapularis" to examine the subscapularis complex. Ultrasound scans will be read and the integrity of the subscapularis complex will be determined by the clinician to be "intact", "attenuated", "partial tear" or "complete tear".
secondaryOutcomes.timeFrame: Collected once at either the 6 month, 1 year or 2 year timepoint.

secondaryOutcomes.measure: American Shoulder and Elbow Surgeons (ASES) subjective survey
secondaryOutcomes.description: A combination of objective measures and patient-reported outcomes, it measures pain and functional limitations in the shoulder. The objective questionnaire allows documentation of range of motion in the patient.
secondaryOutcomes.timeFrame: Collected at pre-op, 9 weeks, 26 weeks, 1 year and 2 year post-op timepoints.

secondaryOutcomes.description: Provides a standardized way of recording the function of a shoulder before and after treatment.
secondaryOutcomes.timeFrame: Collected at pre-op, 9 weeks, 26 weeks, 1 year and 2 year post-op timepoints.

secondaryOutcomes.description: The standard measure for pain on a 0-10 scale, 10 being the worst.
secondaryOutcomes.timeFrame: Collected at pre-op, 9 weeks, 26 weeks, 1 year and 2 year post-op timepoints.

secondaryOutcomes.measure: Western Ontario Osteoarthritis of the Shoulder Index (WOOS)
secondaryOutcomes.description: A patient administrated questionnaire for measurement of the quality of life. It provides scores on four domains: 1.) physical symptoms, 2.) sport, recreation, and work, 3.) lifestyle and 4.) emotions.
secondaryOutcomes.timeFrame: Collected at pre-op, 9 weeks, 26 weeks, 1 year and 2 year post-op timepoints.

secondaryOutcomes.description: A self-administered health measure. Answers are summarized into two scores, a Physical Component Score and a Mental Component Score, which provides an important contrast between the respondents' physical and psychological health status.
secondaryOutcomes.timeFrame: Collected at pre-op, 9 weeks, 26 weeks, 1 year and 2 year post-op timepoints.

secondaryOutcomes.description: Asks patients to rate shoulder pain as a percentage of normal.
secondaryOutcomes.timeFrame: Collected at pre-op, 9 weeks, 26 weeks, 1 year and 2 year post-op timepoints.

secondaryOutcomes.description: A patient administered form that asks patients to evaluate their expectations of their scheduled Arthroplasty procedure.
A patient administered form that asks patients to determine the effect that their shoulder has had on their employment.
secondaryOutcomes.timeFrame: Collected at pre-op, 26 weeks and 1 year.

secondaryOutcomes.description: A patient administered form that asks patient to evaluate if their expectations were met regarding their Arthroplasty procedure.
secondaryOutcomes.timeFrame: Collected at the 1 year and 2 year timepoints.

eligibilityModule.eligibilityCriteria:
Inclusion Criteria:

1. Patient is scheduled to undergo a reverse shoulder arthroplasty procedure using the Arthrex ReversTM system.
2. Patient voluntarily consents to participate in the study and has the mental and physical ability to participate in the study, fill out subjective questionnaires, return for follow-up visits, and comply with prescribed post-operative physical therapy.
3. Patient meets FDA cleared indications for reverse shoulder arthroplasty
4. Patient is between 18-100 years old
5. Patient agrees to also be enrolled in the Arthrex Total Shoulder Registry Study
6. Patient has a standard of care pre-operative CT taken within 6 months that has been submitted for Arthrex Virtual Implant Positioning TM (VIP) planning

Exclusion Criteria:

1. Patient has a history of ipsilateral shoulder arthroplasty
2. A history of shoulder septic arthritis
3. A full thickness subscapularis tear
4. An acute or malunited proximal humeral fracture
5. Chronic locked dislocation
6. Rheumatoid arthritis
7. Tumors
8. Axillary nerve damage
9. Non-functioning deltoid muscle
10. Glenoid vault deficiency precluding baseplate fixation
11. Infection and neuropathic joints
12. Known or suspected non-compliance, drug or alcohol abuse
13. Patients incapable of judgement or under tutelage
14. Inability to follow the procedures of the study, e.g. due to language problems, psychological disorders, dementia, contraindication for imaging etc.
15. The subject is related to investigator as family members, employees, or other dependent persons
16. Any prior open anterior shoulder surgery that included takedown of the subscapularis tendon or violation of the subscapularis tendon (i.e. Latarjet, Bristow)
